stem: In IgA vasculitis, a palpable purpuric rash appears on the lower extremities. This cutaneous finding reflects inflammation of which vessel type?

choices.A: Small vessels (postcapillary venules) with IgA deposition

rationale_correct: IgA (Henoch–Schönlein) vasculitis is a small-vessel leukocytoclastic vasculitis affecting postcapillary venules with IgA immune complex deposition.

rationale_distractors.B: Large-vessel vasculitides (e.g., giant cell) do not cause palpable purpura.
rationale_distractors.C: Medium-vessel vasculitis (e.g., PAN) produces different cutaneous findings (livedo, nodules).
rationale_distractors.D: DVT is venous thrombosis, not small-vessel leukocytoclastic vasculitis.
rationale_distractors.E: Lymphatic inflammation causes lymphedema/lymphangitis, not purpura.

evidence.citation: Anderson A. CIL – Multisystem autoimmune diseases. Dec 11, 2024.
